dialog.line: They don't know what it means, but I heard year 5 pupils insulting each other with the word 'gay'.
It's a sad thing that children have always been nasty to each other, but I think they can learn not to be.
There's all this teasing. Weight, hair colour, 'gay'. It's as if it's always there beneath the surface if we aren't watchful.
I think it is, but personally I don't think children are all little monsters who need civilising. I prefer to think that most of them are good and need the right climate to influence the others.
I used to be that idealistic too.
Don't try to fool me with your cynicism, I know better.
The teasing is better than it was, but I agree there's too much of it.
also happens too often that you see someone being shunned from a group. It doesn't always happen for long, but it happens.
But that's not really bullying is it? Surely that's just friendships groups changing.
One shades into the other. I see a lot of it in the playground remember, the signals of who isn't welcome, who gets invited to play, that kind of thing.
One thing we can do is make a really positive thing about standing up against bullying. I've been checking up on the Diana Memorial Anti-Bullying Award.
They've just set up this special Anti-Bullying Award, and it's open to anyone up to 18. We can nominate up to 6 children, or even a group of up to 30, but I don't think that's us, somehow.
So we make an award in, what, a year's time?
Whenever we like. I've got a candidate already, actually, Justine Massey.

The good thing is she hasn't told anyone about this herself, but I know her mother (she's a teacher at the comprehensive) and she's just been a fantastic little sister to her big brother. He's been having a bad time with some bullies at his school and his youth club. And there's more: the Jones twins have told me she and Nadine have been going home with little Steve on the bus because some nasty girl from the big school has been making his life a misery, teasing him about his appearance. They've really been sticking up for him, especially Justine.
What a little star. Let's go for it. What do we have to do?
